basics.name: Nick Trombley
basics.label: Creative autodidact, passionate about thinking, making, and living.

work.name: Unaffiliated
work.summary: I made the difficult decision to leave Epic in the spring of 2019. While I enjoyed the work, it felt like I had started to stagnate, and over time I saw less and less of a future for myself either at Epic or in Madison. Luckily, I had the luxury of a savings that has enabled me to take a good amount of time off, and I haven't wasted it: I spent a bit of time living abroad, worked on personal projects (including this website), and just generally tried to come to an understanding of who I am and how I want my work to fit into the world. It has been a necessary and successful change.
highlights: Traveled to Japan, Singapore, and London

work.name: Epic
work.description: With the patient at the heart.
work.summary: Epic's User Experience Design team is a small, but highly visible group of exceptionally talented individuals, who work as the lead interaction and visual designers for several development teams. We met with, interviewed, and shadowed end users to understand their needs, responded to technical constraints, and worked alongside developers to create intuitive enterprise applications that make life better for patients and healthcare professionals everywhere. As one of only two designer-developer 'slashies', I also had the opportunity not just to design, but to code many of the projects I worked on, often focused on improving design tools and processes.
highlights: Guided design direction of Epic's products.
Designed and developed tools for designers and developers.
Taught classes on design research, aesthetics, and ethics.

work.name: Epic
work.description: With the patient at the heart.
work.summary: At Epic, Technical Solutions Engineers go far beyond 'turn it off an on again' tech support. As the main point of contact for a focused set of some of the best hospitals in the world, we're relied on to diagnose problems, identify solutions, and manage the implementation of those solutions, often across multiple physical locations and stakeholders.
highlights: Provided tech support for our analytics toolset.
Optimized SQL queries and data transfer performance.
Designed and developed web-based ETL performance dashboard.
Taught classes on effective information design.

references.name: A.S.
references.reference: Nick was an invaluable member of our team at Epic. On top of his normal high quality design work, he proactively helped code and design internal tools (one of which was so successful and helpful that Epic opened it up to customers too). His knowledge of data visualization principles and techniques were of constant help, and the various educational design presentations he made to hundreds of our staff (including both designers and non-designers) were some of their favorites. Nick would be a strong asset to any user-centered team.
